Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Modified Ligation Procedure and Stapled Haemorrhoidectomy for Symptomatic Haemorrhoids

Trial_Design.evidence: single-centre, randomised, single-blind trial enrolled patients aged 18–80 years with symptomatic second- to fourth-degree haemorrhoids from May 2018 to September 2021

Participants.evidence: patients aged 18–80 years with symptomatic second- to fourth-degree haemorrhoids from May 2018 to September 2021

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised 1:1 to MLPPH or SH

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and cost-effectiveness of a modified ligation procedure for prolapsed haemorrhoids (MLPPH) compared to stapled haemorrhoidectomy (SH) in patients with symptomatic haemorrhoids.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the 6-month cure rate.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was stratified by haemorrhoid grade using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment via opaque envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not applied to participants or clinicians.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Of 187 patients screened, 133 were randomised (67 to MLPPH, 66 to SH).

Number_Analysed.evidence: One patient in the MLPPH group was excluded, and two were lost to follow-up.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The 6-month cure rate was significantly higher in the MLPPH group (90.6%) compared to the SH group (69.7%) (P = 0.003).
